ygData.subject: Re: Looking for a few good men (and women)
ygData.msgSnippet: Overhead  o-ver-hed adj 1 :  business expense not chargeable to a particular part of the work or product. I bid, sell and perform engineering services.
ygData.messageBody:
Overhead \ o-ver-hed\ adj 1 : business expense not chargeable to a
particular part of the work or product.

I bid, sell and perform engineering services. Overhead is a constant in ANY
business. As Webster's dictionary (see above) states the overhead cost for
a business is not billable to a particular product or part of a product. It
is, however, passed along to the consumer in the form of a generally higher
price. GM, and any other business MUST, as a necessity, pass along the
costs of health insurance, equipment maintenance, downtime, quality
assurance and yes...even employee incompetence to the consumer. Not in the
1st car off the assembly line or the 2nd or the 200th. But as an average of
the products they sell the overhead must be covered or the company simply
fails to make money.
We do not live in an altruistic society. GM is not in business because it
longs to provide a job to all those poor UAW union members. They are in
business to MAKE MONEY.

The trick to handling overhead is to pass along as much of it as possible to
the consumer and still make a profit. When, in the name of selling your
product, you lower your price to the point that the overhead % is higher
than your profit you lose.

As a consulting engineer my corporate overhead rate is 131%. This means
that, as I bid work, I must take my actual hourly rate and multiply it by
131% just to BREAK EVEN.

Bah. This is no place for a lesson in economics.
If some idiot wants to eat all of his failures let him. I certainly wont.
-----Original Message-----
From: David Bradshaw <Logain@...>
To: EQ_SMITHS@onelist.com <EQ_SMITHS@onelist.com>
Date: Monday, July 12, 1999 6:59 PM
Subject: Re: [EQ_SMITHS] Looking for a few good men (and women)


>From: "David Bradshaw" <Logain@...>
>
>So your saying that most business lose money? I mean if I pay for materials
>and the worker that works on those materials only the company is going to
>lose money right?
>
>Hmmmmm I wonder why they are still in business doesn't make much sense to
>me. I think you should take a close look at what you are saying. If no one
>pays for overhead then the business loses money. SOMEONE must pay for it,
>the workers driving the forklift and the forklift itself do NOT work for
>free. I don't know of any business that loses money and stays open for very
>long. Unless of course it is run by a government.... HEHE Hope none of you
>work for the government or I will have to go get my asbestos undies.
>
>Anyway I am not going to argue this point anymore =) If you still don't
>agree then we will have to agree to disagree.
>
>Thump
>-----Original Message-----

>>Fleetwood, the top maker of moter homes and RV's, Pella, the number one
>maker
>>of window, GM (which has been mentioned) all will tell you the same thing,

>>much work that others do is NOT what the costumer buys. The customer buys
>>what it takes to make the product and that is all. They are not paying
for
>>the time it takes to train John Doe, not for the time it takes for someone
>to
>>fix or check his work. They do not pay for the people to run the accounts,
>>they do not pay for the guy to drive around on a forklift. Would you?
>>
>>When you buy something, do you want to pay for all that extra that had
>>nothing to do with building your car? You can say it did have something
to
>>do with your car, but the fact of the matter it isn't. Efficency is the
>key.
>> If the people doing the paid for work are good enough, then THEY pay the
>>cost of all that excess. I don't charge people for me learning to smith,
I
>>don't charge for failure rates. I charge for my work and the matrials
>needed
>>to make the given item. I have about the same prices. I guess I just
>value
>>my work more then you do yours.
>>
>>Talthoron
